link.title: Infrastructure Migration
link.content: For various reasons, we may decide to move our services off of one platform onto another. This could be due to pricing, uptime or other reasons. In this episode, we look at migrating a Ruby on Rails application and database from Heroku to Fly.

link.title: Hotwire Introduction
link.content: Hotwire is an alternative approach to building modern web applications without using much JavaScript by sending HTML instead of JSON over the wire. With Rails 7, we get Hotwire added in by default. In this episode, we look at some of the features with Hotwire and how to use them.

link.title: Automate Rake Tasks
link.content: When rake tasks need to be part of a deployment, you could find yourself in a situation where the rake task was forgotten about or have to go through the process of shelling into the environment to execute the tasks. In this episode, we look at addressing these issues by creating a way to have rake tasks execute automatically.

link.title: Ubuntu Desktop
link.content: Ubuntu is an open source software operating system that offers a great development experience and can run on most x86/amd64 systems. In this episode, we set up our Ruby on Rails development environment on Ubuntu 22.04 LTS Jammy Jellyfish.

link.title: File Uploads and Cloud Storage
link.content: AWS S3 has been a reliable service over the years and for a long time it was the only option. However, in the past few years, there has been more cloud storage options that have popped up with compatible S3 APIs. These services can sometimes offer better pricing and speeds.

link.title: Roles from Scratch
link.content: In this episode, we look at different authorization approaches from the most simple to more complex scenarios.

link.title: Active Record Tricks
link.content: In this episode, we look at tips and tricks from read only attributes, inserting and upserting (update or insert) records, toggling booleans, and single table inheritance.

link.title: Label Maker with Ruby
link.content: Learn how to turn your tweets into physical printouts on a label maker via the Cups/PPD API. It's a silly concept, but can have some great real world application with interfacing with printers.

link.title: Remote Development
link.content: Having a fast and expensive computer to do daily development is a luxury. Sometimes, we may be in a position where we are just getting started with programming and the budget is very small. In this episode we look at a very moderately priced Chromebook and explore how we can make it into a viable development machine.

link.title: Hotwire Modals
link.content: In this episode, we look at creating an unobtrusive and efficient way to launch Bootstrap modals using Turbo and Stimulus.

link.title: Deploying Static Sites
link.content: Github Pages and Gitlab Pages are both great places to quickly and easily push up static sites directly from your code repository.

link.title: Dabbling with Turbo
link.content: In this episode, we explore some of the new features with Turbo and interactions that we can do with little or no javascript.

link.title: Speeding Up Requests
link.content: In this episode, we look at several issues around pagination and different kinds of querying that could affect performance when working with large datasets.

link.title: Error Tracking from Scratch
link.content: In this episode, we look at creating a middleware to track errors to publish to another error "from scratch" error monitoring application.

link.title: esbuild for Rails
link.content: Use esbuild to bundle your JavaScript, then deliver it via the asset pipeline in Rails. This gem provides an installer to get you going with esbuild in a new Rails application.

link.title: Importmaps in Rails 7
link.content: Import maps let you import JavaScript modules using logical names that map to versioned/digested files – directly from the browser. This will be a default in the upcoming Rails 7.

link.title: Hotwire Turbo Replacing Rails UJS
link.content: In this episode, we look at some common functionality that we got with Rails UJS and what it looks like to reimplement these with Hotwire's Turbo and StimulusJS.

link.title: Tracking Events with Ahoy
link.content: Analytics can provide great information about your users and the content that you're producing. With using the Ahoy gem, we can gather powerful analytics without handing them over to third parties.

link.title: 10 Tips and Tricks
link.content: I don't get around to doing these too often, but they are always a lot of fun. In this episode, we'll look at ten different Ruby on Rails tips and tricks.

link.title: Building a Questionnaire
link.content: Using StimulusJS and nested forms, we create the first parts of a questionnaire. Dynamic surveys can be difficult to architect and maintain. In this episode, we take a simple approach to creating questionnaires.

link.title: Multiple Resources with Devise
link.content: Sometimes we get into situations where our applications requires a different type of user account which wouldn't really fit into a role. So, in this episode we look at creating multiple resources for authentication with Devise.

link.title: Turbo Native for iOS
link.content: In this episode, we look at modifying our Rails application and building a hybrid native application for iOS using Hotwire.

link.title: reCAPTCHA v2
link.content: Reduce the number of bots and spam your Ruby on Rails application gets with Google reCAPTCHA v2.

link.title: Diving into Hotwire
link.content: In this episode, we look at the installation scripts of Hotwire and get a better understanding of what they're doing in order to integrate it into our applications more efficiently.

link.title: Hotwire
link.content: Hotwire is the newest magic which takes a different approach to building modern web applications without using much JavaScript.

link.title: The Stimulus 2.0 Tutorial
link.content: Stimulus 2.0 has been released and with it comes new features, changes and bug fixes. In this episode, we look at adding Stimulus in our application, exploring the new features, and looking at what has changed.

link.title: A Rubyist's Apple M1 Review
link.content: A broad look into the Apple M1 from the perspective of a Ruby Developer. We look at a lot of the different aspects; Docker, asdf Ruby, Visual Studio Code, and more.

link.title: From Editor to IDE
link.content: Visual Studio Code is a powerful editor by itself, but with the addition of a few extensions, we can turn it into a much more intelligent IDE.

link.title: Benchmark Ruby Code
link.content: It's easy to accidentally write slow code in our applications. In this episode, we look at how we can benchmark our code and examples of some methods which are slower than others.

link.title: GitHub Actions
link.content: GitHub Actions makes it easy to automate all your software workflows, now with world-class CI/CD. Build, test, and deploy your code right from GitHub. In this episode, learn to set up GitHub Actions on your Ruby on Rails application with automated tests, code coverage reporting, and security testings.

link.title: Apple Silicon Developer Transition Kit
link.content: First look at the upcoming Apple Silicon processor and what it will be like for us Ruby Developers. Honestly, I wish that it was a better experience. However, with macOS Big Sur being beta and the DTK not being the final consumer hardware, there's still hope yet.

link.title: Soft Delete with Discard
link.content: Soft deletes for ActiveRecord done right.

link.title: Tracking Changes on Action Text
link.content: Without using any gems, we look at tracking changes within Action Text. It seems like a simple thing, but challenges arise through several layers of abstraction due to the flexibility that Action Text provides.

link.title: Contributing to a Gem
link.content: So, you've been using a gem for some time and you've either discovered that the gem isn't working correctly or that you want to start contributing to the gem itself. Sometimes this can be an overwhelming task. In this episode, we look at the basic processes for contributing to a gem.

link.title: Google Maps API with StimulusJS
link.content: Add unobtrusive maps to your application using StimulusJS to tie in Google Maps Javascript API and Places API.

link.title: Syntax Highlighting with Action Text
link.content: Set up Action Text with client side Syntax Highlighting using Highlight.js.

link.title: Emojis from Scratch
link.content: In this episode, we look at attaching emojis to our comments model, allowing them to fill in some emotional cues.

link.title: Like Relationships and Global ID
link.content: In this episode we create a Like/Unlike system where users can like posts and use Global ID to obfuscate IDs.

link.title: From jQuery to ES6
link.content: jQuery has been a great tool for many years, but we've seen a transition in the past years where applications have dropped jQuery and moved to vanilla javascript. In this episode, we look at some common jQuery examples and the ES6 equivalencies.

link.title: Plugging in AnyCable
link.content: ActionCable can handle quite a bit of traffic, but it gets to a point where it can become a burden on the server. With AnyCable, we can not only handle more traffic, but it is also lighter on the resources.

link.title: Ruby on Rails Tips and Tricks
link.content: Ruby and Ruby on Rails tricks from, dot files, operators, bundling, StimulusJS and more.

link.title: Push Notifications with ActionCable
link.content: In this episode, we look into using Push Notifications within our Rails application and then using ActionCable to broadcast Push Notifications to the user.

link.title: Working with Large Data
link.content: When database tables get large, things can slow down significantly. In this episode, we look at a few things which helps keep databases performant and the client side responsive.

link.title: Introduction to Dragon Ruby
link.content: Dragon Ruby is toolchain that allows developers the ability to build apps and games in Ruby.

link.title: Teaching at Bootcamps with Ed Toro
link.content: Ed Toro speaks to his experience at bootcamps from a teacher's perspective. We gain a different perspective of what bootcamps are like. Ed shares valuable information whether you're considering getting into coding or currently at a bootcamp.

link.title: Inline Editing Records
link.content: Using Rails UJS, we create an interactive row editing solution without using any kind of Javascript frameworks.

link.title: Interview with Riaz Virani
link.content: Riaz talks about his experience with organizing and hosting the Atlanta Ruby Users Group meetup. We discuss sponsors, hidden costs of hosting meetups and general tips for guests.

link.title: Nested Forms from Scratch with StimulusJS
link.content: Using StimulusJS controllers, adding nested forms to a Rails application is easy and unobtrusive. In this episode, we look at an alternative way of creating nested forms without the Cocoon gem.

link.title: Interview with Frank Rietta
link.content: In this interview, Frank Rietta, a security expert in web applications, talks about various recommendations for securing a Ruby on Rails application. Many areas are explored from code, staff, servers and infrastructure.

link.title: Introduction to Kubernetes
link.content: In this episode, we take a tour of what Kubernetes is, how to install and configure a local development instance, and deploying a sample application.

link.title: Interview with Jesus Castello
link.content: Jesus Castello talks about the Roda Framework, its uses and stats around its performance.

link.title: What's New in Rails 6
link.content: Overview of notable features coming soon in Ruby on Rails 6.

link.title: What the RegEx?
link.content: In this episode, we look at different ways to use pattern matching with Regular Expressions in Ruby.

link.title: Using Action Text in a Rails 5.2 Application
link.content: With Rails 6.0 is around the corner, Action Text has been merged into the Rails repository. However, it can still be used on a Rails 5.2 application while we wait for its official release.

link.title: Creating a Simple Slack Bot
link.content: Slack is a great application to keep in contact with friends, coworkers and a community. With bots, its capabilities are endless. In this episode, learn how to create a Slack Bot to interact with.

link.title: Grab Bag of Ruby and Ruby on Rails Tricks
link.content: In this episode, we look at various tips and tricks.

link.title: Service Objects for API Interactions with Twilio
link.content: In this episode, learn how to extract the interactions with an external API into a service object so that code is isolated and interchangeable.

link.title: Rails Presenters
link.content: Separating view logic from bloated models can help maintain the model in the long run.

link.title: Improving Partial Loading Performance
link.content: N+1 queries can make an application slow. Having queries called within views can also slow down an app as well as making it less extendable.

link.title: Editors
link.content: One question that I get asked most often is what editor, theme and extensions am I using for my editor. In this episode, we take a look at the different extensions and settings that I use.

link.title: User Notifications
link.content: Using the Notifications Rails Engine, we are able to add notifications to our applications based on certain events. The engine provides the schema and necessary controls and associations to seamlessly integrate into your app.

link.title: Ruby on Rails Development with Microsoft Windows 10
link.content: Developing a Ruby on Rails application on Windows can be difficult, but doesn't have to be with Bash on Windows. Learn how to use Bash to install the Ruby interpreter.

link.title: ActiveRecord Tricks
link.content: In this episode, we look at what would seemingly be simple queries, but are more complex once you start looking into them. Using built in ActiveRecord functions, we can make the queries readable and easy to work with.

link.title: Encrypted Credentials in Rails 5.2
link.content: In this episode, we take a look at the Encrypted Credentials of Ruby on Rails 5.2 and how we can patch it so that we can use other YAML files like a development.yml and test.yml.

link.title: Drifting Ruby Gource
link.content: This is a video of the Drifting Ruby Code Base being built over the years.

link.title: Ruby on Rails - Tips and Tricks
link.content: In this episode, we will go through some of the tips and tricks that we often take for granted. We will be looking at nested routes, scopes, migrations and more.

link.title: Ruby on Rails 5.2.0 Changes and New Features
link.content: Upcoming features include ActiveStorage, built-in Redis Cache Store, updated Rails Credentials and a bunch of other cool things! Honorable mentions also to the new Stimulus Javascript Framework.

link.title: Tracking Errors with Sentry
link.content: Sentry is an Open Source error tracking that helps developers monitor and fix crashes in real time. Learn how to add and configure Sentry to your application.

link.title: Speeding Up Tests
link.content: Slow tests can slow down your development process. Using parallel_tests, you can speed up your test suite by multiple threads and running the tests in groups.

link.title: Sample Data with Factory Bot and Faker
link.content: Factory Bot is a fixtures replacement which can generate the needed records directly in the tests. Faker can be used to create fake data for these records.

link.title: Feature Testing with Capybara
link.content: Create Acceptance Tests or Feature Tests to extend your automated tests with browser testing. It can help tests some areas that cannot be reached with other types of tests.

link.title: Testing with RSpec
link.content: Using RSpec, learn how to create tests for your application and view your coverage.

link.title: Basic Testing Introduction in Rails
link.content: Using the Rails 5.1.X defaults, we have a look at what is configured and explore the different types of tests; using the provided MiniTest and Capybara.

link.title: Creating a Basic Gem
link.content: Gems are a packaged library of functions that can extend your application or provide other features to your system. Learn to create and publish a ruby gem.

link.title: Polymorphic Associations
link.content: Advancing from Single Table Inheritance, learn how Polymorphic Associations differ and tricks to simplify their usage.

link.title: Single Table Inheritance
link.content: Learn to use single table inheritance to allow multiple classes to be stored in the same database table.

link.title: Auditing with Paper Trail
link.content: Using the paper_trail gem, track changes to model records for auditing purposes and rollback changes when required.

link.title: ActiveRecord Migrations
link.content: This episode covers different tips and tricks around database migration files.

link.title: Recurring Events with FullCalendar
link.content: Create recurring events and interact with them on FullCalendar.

link.title: Recurring Events with ice_cube
link.content: ice_cube is a ruby library for easily handling repeated events and schedules.

link.title: Restricting Access by IP Address
link.content: Learn to lock down your application or parts of your application by IP Addresses.

link.title: Custom Error Pages with Slack Notification
link.content: Learn to use custom error pages to provide a similar look to your application. Get notified on Slack as errors occur to act on them before they're reported.

link.title: Benchmarking and Refactoring the content_for View Helper
link.content: In a recent blog post, we looked into the content_for view helper to render breadcrumbs. Once we got the feature working, it's time to refactor the feature to lower technical debt.

link.title: Creating Custom Ruby on Rails Generators
link.content: Simplify your workflow by using custom generators to streamline the creation of files and templates that you use often.

link.title: Virtual Columns with JSON Data Types
link.content: Continuing from Episode #87, we take a deeper dive into virtual columns in Rails 5.1 and use them to parse JSON Data Types with adding indexes to the virtual column.

link.title: Virtual Columns in MySQL
link.content: In Ruby on Rails 5.1.0, generated virtual column support was added for MySQL and MariaDB. Using generated and stored columns can leverage heavy calculations to the SQL side.

link.title: Plotting Points on a Map from Scratch
link.content: Using the Google Maps Javascript API, learn how to plot markers onto a map. Load markers and info windows through AJAX calls to your Rails JSON API.

link.title: Working with Subdomains
link.content: Learn to create a multi-tenant application where access to tenants are determined by the subdomain.

link.title: Geocoding, Places and Maps
link.content: Using the Geocoder gem and Google APIs, learn how to add some geolocation functionality to your application.

link.title: Autocomplete with HTML Results
link.content: Working with an autocomplete can be very simple. However, things get complicated when you try to use HTML markup in the displayed results. Learn how to use HTML markup within your autocomplete results!

link.title: DataTables
link.content: The DataTables Javascript library creates a powerful display of your application's data. Some of the features include pagination, server side processing, sorting and search.

link.title: Bootstrap Framework and Ruby on Rails
link.content: Using Bootstrap in your application has become much more simple. Also learn to create some helper methods to make working with Bootstrap much easier.

link.title: Routing Partials
link.content: The routes file can grow to be unmaintainable and messy. Learn to keep things organized by extracting out blocks of routes into their own files.

link.title: Mountable Engines
link.content: Mountable Engines are a great way to extract code into its own namespace and allow the code to be reused in other applications. Other popular gems that are mountable engines are Devise and Doorkeeper.

link.title: Counter Cache Associations
link.content: When displaying a count of records, this will generate extra SQL Queries. Learn how to reduce the number of SQL queries called with counter caching the number of associated records.

link.title: Cropping Images with JCrop
link.content: Extend your image upload functionality with JCrop. Learn to redirect the user to a crop page once they have uploaded their image and save versions of the cropped images.

link.title: Javascript Select Form Fields with Chosen
link.content: Chosen is a jQuery plugin that makes long, unwieldy select boxes much more user-friendly. Learn how to use Chosen in a few different ways in this episode; Rails form builder and Simple Form.

link.title: Drag and Drop with Interact.js
link.content: Using Interact.js to create draggable and droppable items in our view, we can use AJAX callbacks on events to interact with our Ruby on Rails application. Also, learn how to use Ruby Assets to manage our Javascript Libraries.

link.title: Page Specific Javascript in Ruby on Rails
link.content: Sometimes you may find yourself with an application that has javascript that needs to execute only on a specific page. This episode lays the foundation to easily manage page specific javascript.

link.title: Pagination with Kaminari
link.content: When displaying a significant number of records, it is often a basic functions in a web application is to paginate the records and load them as requested.

link.title: Intro to Docker on Windows
link.content: Developing a Ruby on Rails application on Windows can be difficult, but doesn't have to be with Docker. Learn how to use Docker to create isolated containers and get them to talk with the Rails app and passed through to the local computer.

link.title: Nested Forms with Cocoon
link.content: Using the unobtrusive gem, Cocoon, learn how to handle multiple models in a single form with accepts_nested_attributes_for.

link.title: Nested Forms from Scratch
link.content: Learn how to handle multiple models in a single form with accepts_nested_attributes_for and learn how to add and remove nested records through JavaScript.

link.title: Ruby on Rails 5.1.0 Changes and New Features
link.content: Upcoming features include Yarn/Webpack, System Tests via Capybara, Encrypted Secrets and a bunch of other cool things!

link.title: Working with Internationalization
link.content: Adding translations into your website does not have to be hard. With Rails built in I18N functionality, we gain access to many helpers and conventions that makes it a much easier task. Learn how to add I18N into your Rails application.

link.title: Decoding and Interacting with Barcodes
link.content: Using the QuaggaJS Library, learn how to scan and decode barcodes with your Ruby on Rails application. Using provided callbacks, interact with controller actions to provide a seamless experience.

link.title: Managing Servers with Ansible
link.content: A look into the Drifting Ruby network architecture and how I manage deployments with Ansible.

link.title: Searchkick and Elasticsearch
link.content: Add full text searching using Searchkick and Elasticsearch. Here I will show the steps involved in adding this search to an existing application and a sample of autocomplete functionality.

link.title: Random Ruby Tips and Tricks
link.content: A collection of different Ruby tips and tricks. Hope you find some of them useful!

link.title: Client Side Encryption
link.content: Add an extra level of security to your application with client side encryption. Even over an SSL connection, there are attacks which could expose your users' sensitive information. Using JSEncrypt, learn how to encrypt on the client side and decrypt on the server side.

link.title: Security and Static Code Analyzers
link.content: Whether you're preparing for a third-party security scan or already doing peer code reviews, you should always run brakeman scanner on your application to identify potential security vulnerabilities.

link.title: Periodic Tasks with sidekiq-cron
link.content: Using a third-party add-on, sidekiq-cron, we can create periodic tasks to extend the functionality of sidekiq.

link.title: Sidekiq on Production
link.content: Sidekiq is a Ruby Background Processor that manages its queue with a Redis service. Learn to deploy Sidekiq to your production environment.

link.title: Sidekiq Basics
link.content: Sidekiq is a Ruby Background Processor that manages its queue with a Redis service. Learn the basics of Sidekiq and integrating it with ActiveJob.

link.title: Mail Previews and Templates
link.content: Using ActionMailer::Preview preview email samples without sending them. Using Zurb's Foundation for Emails, learn how to use email templates with the Ink framework.

link.title: Getting Started - Ruby on Rails - Architectural Overview
link.content: For beginners, learn the basic structure of a Ruby on Rails application and the request lifecycle. Learn how different components of a Rails application interact with each other.

link.title: Redis Basics
link.content: Redis within a Ruby on Rails application has many benefits. Learn to interact with Redis Server and set it up for caching within your application.

link.title: Charts and Graphs
link.content: Learn how to use one of three charting libraries, Chart.js, Highcharts, or Google Charts, using the Chartkick gem to create simple and unobtrusive charts in your application.

link.title: Getting Started - Ruby on Rails - Development Environment
link.content: Here is a simple workflow of setting up a new development environment. From Homebrew, ZSH, Atom, and RVM, learn how to easily get your macOS environment up and running.

link.title: Database Index Optimization and Migration Maintenance
link.content: Adding indexes to your databases can increase the SQL search performance on your tables. As your application grows, migration files can become out of hand, use squasher to squish them down to a single file.

link.title: Rails API - Throttling with Rack::Attack
link.content: Save expensive calculation time using Rack::Attack, we will learn how to limit requests coming into our application. This gem not only limits requests, but can be used to blacklist or whitelist users as well.

link.title: Rails API - Authentication with JWT
link.content: Using the knock gem, we will add JWT Authentication to our Rails API Application.

link.title: Rails API - Active Model Serializer
link.content: Using ActiveModel::Serializer, learn how to create the JSON responses for your Rails API application. ASM is a great object oriented approach to building a JSON API.

link.title: Rails API Basics
link.content: A brief introduction on Rails API. Learn how to create an API application and setup the routes. This episode is paving the way for more in depth looks into Rails API.

link.title: Version Control with Git Flow
link.content: Using Git Flow, learn how to work with branches and organize your changes. Once you have completed features, learn how to merge them back into a develop branch and prepare for a release to your master branch.

link.title: Authorization with Pundit
link.content: Prevent unauthorized access to your application with Pundit; an authorization library for Ruby on Rails which restricts what resources a given user is allowed to access.

link.title: Two Factor Authentication
link.content: Add multi factor authentication to your existing authentication solution. This gives your users the option to increase the level of security to their account and help prevent unauthorized access.

link.title: Authentication Crash Course with Devise
link.content: Devise is a flexible authentication solution for Rails based on Warden. Learn how to add a stable authentication solution like Devise to your application.

link.title: Capturing Signatures with Signature Pad
link.content: Using the Javascript Library, Signature Pad, learn how to capture user signatures and store them within your Ruby on Rails application.

link.title: Antivirus Uploads with Clamby
link.content: Using ClamAV, scan files uploaded to your application for viruses. In the event of a virus learn how to gracefully handle the infected file and notify the user.

link.title: FullCalendar Events and Scheduling
link.content: Learn how to incorporate FullCalendar into your Ruby on Rails application with listing and creating events. Using unobtrusive javascript, we can create a fast interactive calendar.

link.title: DRY up your Javascript
link.content: Learn how avoid duplicate code to reuse existing javascript.

link.title: puma-dev replacement for pow and prax
link.content: Puma-dev is the emotional successor to pow. It provides a quick and easy way to manage apps in development on OS X; supporting web sockets and ssl.

link.title: ActionCable - Part 3 - Securing Your WebSockets
link.content: Using authentication and authorization, lock down your ActionCable WebSockets so that messages are only sent and received to the intended users.

link.title: ActionCable - Part 2 - More Complex Example
link.content: Extending the previous episode, we look into making a realtime poll application where users can get live feedback on voting.

link.title: ActionCable - Part 1 - Configuration and Basics
link.content: A walkthrough on configuring ActionCable with Rails 5. Learn how to configure your mount points and the basics of using ActionCable with your Rails application.

link.title: ActionController::Renderer
link.content: ActionController::Renderer allows you to render arbitrary templates without requirement of being in controller actions.

link.title: Importing and Exporting CSV Data
link.content: Basics on importing and exporting CSV Data using Ruby and without gems.

link.title: Playing with JSON
link.content: Some neat tips and tricks for interacting with and parsing JSON responses from an API.

link.title: Progressive Render
link.content: Slow content got you down? Load it later! Use this gem to defer loading of portions of your page until after load. They will be fetched via AJAX and placed on the page when ready.

link.title: Client Side Validations
link.content: Give early warning to users of form errors before they submit. With client side validations, the user can correct any errors prior to submitting the form.

link.title: Production Deployment on Ubuntu
link.content: A guide to configure your Ubuntu installation and deploy a Ruby on Rails application. Lock down the settings to prevent unwanted access.

link.title: Eager Loading with Goldiloader
link.content: Wouldn't it be awesome if ActiveRecord didn't make you think about eager loading and it just did the "right" thing by default? With Goldiloader it can!

link.title: Infinite Scrolling
link.content: Infinite scrolling is now a common feature and there are several cases where it is really useful. For instance there are some websites where we simply can’t imagine a good pagination system, like Twitter or even Facebook.

link.title: WYSIWYG Editor with Trix
link.content: Compose beautifully formatted text in your web application. Trix is a WYSIWYG editor for writing messages, comments, articles, and lists.

link.title: WYSIWYG Editor with Summernote
link.content: Integrate Summernote WYSIWYG Editor into your application. Learn how to use AJAX callbacks to filestore your images instead of database Base64.

link.title: Meta Tags
link.content: Adding Meta Tags to your website is important for SEO ranking and content display. Learn how to easily add meta tags to your Ruby on Rails application.

link.title: Faye WebSockets - Part 2
link.content: Learn how to install and configure a thin server within a Linux environment hosting a Faye WebSocket application. This episode includes showing you how to server your WebSockets over a secure SSL connection.

link.title: Fragment Caching
link.content: Make your application faster by leveraging memory and caching fragments of your view.

link.title: UUID in Rails with ActiveUUID
link.content: Some cases require non-auto incrementing primary keys as well as multiple master writes without id conflicts. With ActiveUUID, we can configure our table's primary key with confidence without added complexity.

link.title: Faye WebSockets - Part 1
link.content: Using WebSockets, we are able to create a realtime notification between browsers. Useful for in-app messaging, chats, and more! Learn how to use Faye's Publish and Subscribe methods. I believe that this paves the way for successfully using and learning the upcoming ActionCable.

link.title: Not RJS and Turbolinks - Part 2
link.content: A continuation from Episode 20 where we explore rendering the user's edit pages in a modal on a per request basis. Instead of rendering all modals for the users in the index, we will request them using remote javascript.

link.title: Not RJS and Turbolinks
link.content: Using Javascript responses, we can make our Rails application have a quick and responsive Single Page Application feel to it.

link.title: Deleting and Undeleting with Paranoia
link.content: When your app is using Paranoia, calling destroy on an ActiveRecord object doesn't actually destroy the database record, but just hides it.

link.title: Caching with Dalli
link.content: Dalli is a great interface for Memcached through Ruby.

link.title: Dependent Form Fields
link.content: Using unobtrusive javascript, we can hide certain fields on forms based on the selected values of other fields.

link.title: Complex Strong Parameters
link.content: Make your strong parameters do more by extracting the logic in order to maximize the ability and security of your application.

link.title: Refile Uploads with Progress Bar
link.content: Adding progress bars to your Refile uploader is easy thanks to the included javascript library from Refile. Learn how to add progress bars to your application.

link.title: Securing File Uploads
link.content: Be default, Refile does not have a way to secure file downloads. It relies on a generated hash that is unknown to users unless the page renders that image or has a download to that file. This is okay sometimes, however, protecting the file from being downloaded for those who have the URL is a bit more involved.

link.title: Uploading Files with Refile
link.content: Refile is a modern file upload library for Ruby applications. It is simple, yet powerful. This episode covers the basics of uploading and displaying images. Next episodes will cover protecting files and progress bars.

link.title: Static Pages with High Voltage
link.content: Creating Static Pages within your Rails application is easy and configurable with High Voltage.

link.title: Annotate
link.content: With strong params replacing attr_accessible, a difficulty has arisen with referencing to the structure of your models. With annotate, we can generate the structure of our models in the comments of our models.

link.title: Invisible Captcha
link.content: Part of a good User Experience is making your application easy to use for your users. However, a few bad apples often cause a hinderance to your UX/UI by the addition of Captchas. Learn how to create invisible captchas to protect your forms while delivering a good UX.

link.title: ActiveJob
link.content: ActiveJob is a built in wrapper within Rails 4 for your background processors. By adding this layer to your application, swapping background processors is much easier as you will only be affecting a limited number of files.

link.title: Sending Emails
link.content: This episode is a prelude to ActiveJob and background processing. Learn how to send emails using an external mail service with Rails.

link.title: Sitemap Generator
link.content: Adding Search Engine Optimization to your site is easy. However, maintaining it can be difficult. This episode shows how to approach the sitemap indexing.

link.title: attr_encrypted
link.content: Protecting your data within your database has never been easier. With attr_encrypted, you can easily add a level of security to your application without much refactoring.

link.title: Florrick
link.content: This is a Rails library which integrates with Active Records and provides some awesome user-initiated string interpolations for your web apps. For example, have you ever needed to allow users to insert their own variables into e-mail templates or messages?

link.title: Serialized Attributes
link.content: Store multiple attributes and values using a text column. Not for everyday use, but has situations where it can save on the number of columns and/or models needed to accomplish a task.

link.title: ActionCable on Production
link.content: Taking a look at ActionCable and switching from Puma to Thin. On server reboot, spin up the ActionCable service.

link.title: Impressionist
link.content: A lightweight plugin that logs impressions per action or manually per model

link.title: Pow
link.content: Serve your applications on your development machine with ease. Pow allows a dev domain to your local machine for spinning up linked applications
